captions.text: - Well, here I am.
I'm sitting in bed with my heating pad,
also known as my best friend.
I don't feel like getting out of bed,

I don't see myself getting
out of bed anytime soon.
It's hard to stay positive
and it's hard to not be mad at my body

or at the situation when
this is how I feel, you know?
My name is Laura and I have endometriosis.
I was first diagnosed with endometriosis

in the summer of 2012 when
I was a senior in college.
I have one distinct memory of when

I was on the basketball
team in high school,

and I was at practice,
and I had such bad cramps.
I literally could not do anything.
I was just laying there.
I was vomiting, I was sweating.
Nothing helped, so I went to urgent care.
They just told me I had bad periods,
and that's basically what I was told
up until I was 21 years old.
At many points in my life,

I convinced myself that
maybe I was imagining it,
maybe I was just crazy,

maybe everyone felt this
way on their period,
but there's this certain kind of pain
that comes with endometriosis,

and it's not just around
the time of your period.
It's a pain that lingers always,
and at some point in your life,
you realize that it's not normal.
I came home from work today.
I lasted about an hour before
the pain was just overwhelming.
I was nauseous, I went into the bathroom

and I vomited because I
had such terrible cramps.

Working from home, which is
something that I have to do

at least once a month,
sometimes more often.
My job is to sit at a desk and write,
and sometimes I can't even do that.
When you have a flu, you go to the doctor

and they give you medicine
and you get over it.

When you have endometriosis,
you go to the doctor,

you have a surgery, and then
it comes back a year later.

Realizing that this was
something that I was going

to have to deal with the
rest of my life, just...
I saw all my relationships in the future
just flash before my eyes.

It's very hard to date
and explain to someone,

"Hey, I might not be
able to have sex with you

"and I also might not be able
to have your children, but
"let's date anyway."
I was letting people treat me like dirt
because I felt like I had to make up
for the fact that I was broken.
Today's one of those days where I'm like,

"I can do this, I can
absolutely live with this.
"I'm fine."
I just hope that this lasts.
I have good days and bad days,
usually more bad days than good days,
but maybe this week will be
more good days than bad days.

I'm tired of feeling
like less than a woman
because I may not be able to have sex

and I may not be able
to conceive children.

I know that someday, I'm
going to look in the mirror

and I'm going to forgive my
body for what it has done to me.

I know that I'm going
to look in the mirror
and love the person looking back at me
and accept every part of me.

title: Living With A Chronic Illness: Endometriosis

comments.text: O_O﻿
comments.author: Stu i dont give a a fuck pot (2D)

comments.text: Don't watch these things!
comments.author: 2D “Suzuki” Pot GorillazDraw

comments.text:
Can you please make a series?! I have cold uticaria and cholenergic 
urticaria. these chronic diseases are so rare that the odds of having it 
are literally 1 in a million. cold urticaria is being allergic to cold. 
cholenergic urticaria is being allergic to heat. THIS IS REAL. I AM NOT 
FAKING. I can't join sports, be in sunlight for long, be outside in cool or 
warm temperatures, sweat, or cry. it's also hard for me to take showers, 
swim, or eat/drink cold/hot things. I was diagnosed a couple years ago, 
when I had an anaphylactic reaction to cold. some of my symptoms can be 
similar to those of severe food allergies. since I do have breathing 
problems sometimes, I have to carry an epi pen with me all the time. I am 
currently taking medicines 7 times a day. because of all this, I haven't 
been able to go to school in the past 6 weeks. (AKA: a ton of homework). I 
know it may be difficult for you to find someone with these conditions to 
help you film a video on this, but you have no idea how much this would 
mean to me. please notice this comment. thanks!﻿
comments.author: mellygirl 645

comments.text:
I hope this becomes a series! It was a great video. You should do one about 
tinnitus. I don't know if it's classified as an illness but it's really 
terrible to live with it especially when you know that there's nothing to 
do about it. 
I got tinnitus when I was 13 and I haven't slept a whole night without 
waking up or not been able to fall asleep since then. I just want to be 
able to hear silence again cause it's literally driving me insane. ﻿
comments.author: miscellanea

comments.text:
The amount of tears that just HYDRO PUMPED from my eyes. 
I read a story about a couple and one of them was asexual and the other had 
endo. , it was very cute ( but I didnt know what endo. was so I was a bit 
confused as to why it was more emotional than I felt it was.) And now that 
I know , EVERYTHING MAKES SO MUCH SENSE FROM THAT STORY and im just weeping 
bricks right now.﻿

comments.text:
I don't even know what cramps are like during that time of month. Is this

comments.author: kaitlynosaur

comments.text: Thank you.﻿
comments.author: SlayerAJ

comments.text:
i have PCOS and endometriosis, it's so painful and it does make me let 
people treat me like dirt cause i feel broken... i'm 34 now and i feel very 
concerned about being able to conceive, i had never really tried it before 
and now i'm just terrified it will take a long time or i just won't be able 
to... this is just so frustrating... so watching this has made me feel less 
alone in this... i am aware many women suffer from it but it's not 
something you talk about, so it can get lonely, it makes you feel 
inadequate﻿
comments.author: Alejandra Arrambide

comments.text:
Endometriosis runs in my family. I've gotten several positive signs for it, 
but I've been too terrified to get an official diagnosis. But something is 
definitely wrong when you give yourself burns from your heating pad because 
you'd rather feel that than the cramps.
If you have bad periods, please, please get checked out by a gynecologist. 
Reproductive illness is something women never want to talk about, but it's 
extremely serious.﻿
comments.author: Chel Keller

comments.text:
My mum has endometriosis. She is part of a loving marriage (over 25 years) 
and she also has three children. Guys, there's hope. This isn't something I 
can speak about from experience but I see how my mum fights through this. 
She had a key hole type surgery about 3 years ago and went back and got 
another surgery last October. There's hope, she's shown me that. Live your 
life and own it!﻿
comments.author: Rita Cammaroto

comments.text:
My mom has endometriosis and I have pretty bad periods but do u have a 
higher risk if your family has it ? ﻿
comments.author: Kara McGrath

comments.text: Great vid! I make similar videos if you want to check it out. 😃﻿

comments.text: About ME and Fibromyalga and depression... I should say.

If someone wont date you just because you cant have sex you shouldn't want 
to date them anyway﻿

comments.text: Does anyone with endometriosis suffers of cystitis as well, or is just me?﻿

comments.text: I have this too. ﻿

comments.author: Jakob Jakobson

comments.text:
+Jakob Jakobson I think you will find very few doctors would be willing to 
remove a younger woman's reproductive organs unless it is absolutely 
necessary...And even then they usually won't until they are older. Plus, it 
would mean that she would immediately go through menopause and have to take 
hormone replacement and stuff like that...Which can actually cause some 
people a lot of issues.
comments.author: Shannon O'Driscoll

comments.text: oh, okay, I see.
comments.author: Jakob Jakobson

comments.text:
+Jakob Jakobson It isn't a cure, there is no cure, the womb isn't the 
issue, it's the lining of the womb that grows in areas it shouldn't so you 
need surgery to remove it from the bladder and intestines at times
comments.author: jessyj2006

comments.text:
And remove everything? I'm guessing she wants to have kids from what she 
said, and removing everything would completely crush that idea.
comments.author: Budgiebear23

comments.text:
Great video! I also struggle with chronic illness. I make some videos about 
it some times.﻿
comments.author: Just Gil

comments.text:
Wow. I thought Lara was a new snotty bitch working at BuzzFeed...Looks like 
I shouldn't judge a book from it's cover. :/ Stay strong, Lara.﻿
comments.author: Nicole Sam

comments.text:
my mom had/has endometriosis .. i remember she was always in bed , sick , 
for about a year .. she wasn't there for the family because she was always 
in constant pain . she had her surgery , and she's doing better . but it's 
sad to know that i can't have any more brothers and sisters , and it's good 
to know that i have my little sister at least , she is a blessing , and i 
love her so much . ﻿
comments.author: Kenna Designs

comments.text:
Adenomyosis and Endometriosis. I've tried all sorts of treatment - but in a 
month - I'm getting a hysterectomy because this is controlling my life. And 
I'm tired of it. Much love to anyone out there suffering. ♡﻿
comments.author: Khrys Aiaya

comments.text:
Thank you for making this and so succinctly saying everything I have felt 
for the past 7 years. I was lucky enough to find a GYN (that, oddly enough, 
treated my mother and aunts for endometriosis) who has made living with 
this bearable. ﻿
comments.author: Chelsea Rhodes

comments.text: You go girl! Stay strong﻿
comments.author: Kelsey Imamoto

comments.text:
much respect for her. she's the real mvp. so many girls complain about 
period cramps; but I think I don't even have a right anymore because of 
her. ﻿
comments.author: tinesse xoxo

comments.text: I have endometriosis. It's hell.﻿
comments.author: Chelsea Turner

comments.text: does she really have this desiese?﻿
comments.author: John Toste

comments.text:
I eventually had to have a FULL very invasive hysterectomy. Please report 
any changes to your doctor. Please see a doctor. If that doctor tells you 
it's in your head, FIND ANOTHER ONE. This can save your life. Most people 
don't know that it CAN be life threatening. My uterus, ovaries and even my 
bladder had adhered to my intestines and were up into my stomach. The 
surgeries cause scar tissue. Scar tissue builds. 

Please listen to your guts (pretty much literally), see a doctor regularly 
and track/report ALL changes ﻿
comments.author: Sherlock

comments.text:
I think a lot of us with "invisible illnesses" often wonder if we're just 
imagining and/or exaggerating things. I've thought to myself many times in 
my life that maybe, just maybe, *most* people in this world are in physical 
pain every day, and they just pretend that everything is okay. I still 
wonder, even now, if this is the case. I mean, there's a lot to be said for 
staying positive! But then I hear how people don't share the same issues 
and I'm reminded that many people feel perfectly fine, every day. I envy 
them a bit. Every day I wake up feeling no pain is a day I consider a "good 
day".﻿
comments.author: Rory Triscuit

comments.text:
this was very touching. i admit i was one of the people who judged you by 
your basic girl videos. i take everything back and wish you a less painful 
life.﻿
comments.author: TheMagicalElephant

comments.text:
I think i have this however the doctors are so useless and wont send me to 
get checked for it. I experience the same pain that is described and it 
kills me. I just dont know what im supposed to do anymore. ﻿
comments.author: Aoife Ni Briain

comments.text: Wait, if I have this, I can adopt a child from Africa. Yowza!﻿
comments.author: Pie Butterprints

comments.text:
My mum had endometriosis, it seems to run in my family so there is a good 
chance im going to get endometriosis :(﻿
comments.author: Rose Gay

comments.text:
I cried watching this. You are a very strong person. I don't think that I 
can survive being put in your position. I hope you will have a happy and 
wonderful life despite suffering from that disease.﻿
comments.author: dorothyperkins92

comments.text:
Yup, having endometriosis sucks along with reoccurring abscess sacks on 
both ovaries is he'll at times. I'm older now but I found out i had it when 
I was 19 and it doesn't get better, you can either suck it up and deal with 
the pain or live on pain meds for ever which also suck bcuz of all the 
extra side effects, it's hard enough dealing with the pain and bleeding and 
everything else then to add the possible addiction or pill abuse to the 
list is too much for a busy person to deal with. I say just try to stay 
healthy and get a second opinion if your not comfortable with your doctor's 
diagnosis.﻿
comments.author: Vicki C

comments.text:
I know Plexus (all natural health and wellness supplements) has helped some 
people with their endo, may be worth checking out. Some of my clients have 
been helped by using Plexus.﻿
comments.author: Justine Froelker

comments.text:
I liked and agreed with this video on so many levels. I also was born with 
a syndrome that has similar symptoms and future problems and have wondered 
the same questions I have. It's good to know you aren't the only one 
thinking that way.﻿
comments.author: Samantha Brinton

comments.text:
I was misdiagnosed with this year's ago told I couldn't have kids. Well I 
have 3 kids now. And I only have half of my reproductive system. Anything 
can happen. ﻿
comments.author: Michelle Searls

comments.text:
theres a herbal cure for that if you phone self heal herbs in victoria they 
can help you out .﻿
comments.author: junipuur jupiter

comments.text:
Lara, I just wanted to say thank you for making this video. It made me feel 
a little betyer. Stay strong ❤﻿
comments.author: Elizabeth Meade

comments.text:
And in my previous comment I will say also I would in no way recommend a 
hysterectomy right off the bat for anyone...
I don't think I made that clear... I'm just saying it's what had to be done 
for me.
Sorry if I didn't make that clear.﻿
comments.author: gemery101

comments.text:
I had endometriosis. In 2009 I had my left ovary and a bunch of endo and 
adhesions removed. The adhesions had pulled part of my colon out of place. 
I was glad to have it over, or so I thought. I ended up having more 
problems about 6 months later. A year to the day, I had a hysterectomy (the 
surgeon was able to leave in my right ovary for hormones). I also had more 
endo removed and my appendix because we don't need it. He left my cervix so 
my bladder would have a place to sit and not fall (important to know if you 
consider a hysterectomy).
I've never looked back. Recovery was tough. My body took time to adjust. It 
may not be for everyone. 
I feel for everyone that has ever dealt with it the way my mother and I 
did. People do make you feel like less of a person. Doctors do too. I was 
29 and relieved to finally find a doctor who would take it out as I knew I 
never wanted children. They were so concerned with saving that for me when 
I said "no, my husband and I don't want them. It's not for us". Some made 
me feel like a drug seeker. Some said it was in my head. No. I felt like I 
might die sometimes.
I know that some women desperately want children and the hysterectomy 
option is not right for you. I hope beyond hope for you that it works out. 
My struggle is done sure but I can remember your pain, the emotional and 
physical. While the physical pain is long gone, if I close my eyes the 
emotional is just under the surface still sometimes.
You are never less of a woman. You are never alone.﻿
comments.author: gemery101

comments.text: deep﻿
comments.author: Anavi Arora

comments.text:
TIA MOWRY HAD ENDOMETRIOSIS.. she overcame it after 2 surgeries, then got 
into clean eating/diet and exercise, and then SHE BECAME PREGNANT. don't 
give up. I truly think diet has to do with it.﻿
comments.author: Reeendom12

comments.text:
I have it too and I ended up getting my tubes removed through surgery when 
I removed my iud. The pain is gone but I still have heavy bleeding every 
month. ﻿
comments.author: Dulce Rodriguez

comments.text: OMG- thank you thank you thank you- nobody talks about this﻿
comments.author: punkybrewstar83

comments.text:
My older sister was diagnosed around 14 and is taking birth control for it. 
She is completely normal now, except that she will either need to be on 
birth control or pregnant or else she will become infertile. But she hasn't 
needed surgery or been in pain cause of the meds...﻿
comments.author: Savannah Reid

comments.text:
I had it and had laproscopy twice then a year later a hysterectomy at age 
27. The pain was so severe for about 5 yrs that it almost made me get fired 
from having to ask to go home early many times and spend long times in the 
bathroom. It was like being stabbed with a hot sword and someone twisting 
it. I did have one child threes before having the hysterectomy and those 
labor pains were as bad as the endometriosis pain. I feel for every teen 
and woman that has this.﻿
comments.author: Michelle Gauthier

comments.text:
I don't have endometriosis. But, I have sickle cell which is associated 
with pain and it is nice to see diseases/conditions like this get light 
shined on it. People never get me when I explain my body pains-- they say 
stuff like "Isn't that just your body hurting, not some condition?" people 
never get it and I never know how to explain it. Once a friend of mine had 
tried to explain sickle cell to this mean girl in my grade which made me 
irritated because she didn't have to explain something for me.  But, the 
girl had said one sentence that really stuck out "She could die from it". I 
won't actually because I have a mild version of it luckily. But what really 
hit hard is when the mean girl had replied "So why isn't she dead yet?". I 
can't even explain how I felt. It sucks when people just don't get it or 
act insensitive about it.﻿
comments.author: Jessica Taylor

comments.text: Lara is so beautiful, inside and out.﻿
comments.author: Eric Trujillo

comments.text:
I have this too. It sucks :( I don't get why so many doctors checking me 
out never said anything before a couple of years ago... It's getting worse 
now... Not sure what to do about it﻿
comments.author: lollsazz

comments.text: May there be an effective cure soon! :)﻿
comments.author: PuppetMask

comments.text:
When i was 15, 3 years after getting my first period, I started getting 
ridiculous cramps and vomited almost every time I had my period. However, I 
started taking birth control pills and they helped relieve it, and 
currently my menstruation isn't as bad anymore. Were these symptoms of 
endometriosis?﻿
comments.author: Paula A.

comments.text: Despite what everyone thinks, not everyone wants sex and children.﻿
comments.author: Shaylene Scandale

comments.text:
Hi I'm 16 years old. No one really believes me when I tell them how much 
pain I be in. It hurts sooooo bad every month and I miss school because of 
it . My docs just say it's my ovaries but that's still not helping me . 
Should I go to an obgyn doctor? How do I find out if I have this or not ? I 
even told my mom but she thinks my doctor knows everything. They don't know 
because if they did they would tell me what's wrong and help me . Heating 
pads don't even help me most of the time😭 I'm in pain right now too . It 
sucks:( I just want to find out . My teachers don't believe me sometimes 
and my coaches don't sometimes.﻿
comments.author: Tonika B

comments.text:
My grandmother had this. She was able to have children, it just took a 
really long time, and she had a lot of miscarriages.﻿
comments.author: xXMushfaceXx

comments.text:
This is a really good video. You look extremely beautiful + brave. I 
definitely love the person I see who made this vid. Thanks for telling your 
story. A lot of what you described sounds familiar, I am diagnosed with 
dysmenorrhea, not endiometriosis, but I relate. I can collapse if I am not 
careful on my period, my heart races out of control, my body temp plummets 
low or raises through the roof. I'm convulsing. I want to slap the people 
who say take a midol, aleve or ibuprofen. This feels like I'm being sawed 
in half! My doctor prescribed me opiates for pain, but even they are 
beginning to lose effect. One of the comments that worried me is that you 
can feel even when you are not near your period, so do I. Almost everyday 
of the month there is at least mild pain. Now, that I know more about the 
symptoms from you I'm going to talk about this to my doctors. I hope I 
don't have it, but this video gave me plenty of strength to face it if I 
do.﻿
comments.author: Song Thief

comments.text:
Buzzfeed should also make a video about people with mental disorders, 
people with mental disorders are treated almost as if they were 
somewhat...different, as if they were  another species of human, which 
isn't true.﻿
comments.author: Rochelle Leung

comments.text:
I frequently have vomit-inducing cramps during my period; sex has never 
been an issue for me though. Are there varying degrees of endometriosis? 
Should I be concerned?﻿
comments.author: RiteofWriters

comments.text:
I had to have a hysterectomy at 27. I also had endometriosis. I feel for 
you so much. The pain is horrendous.﻿
comments.author: Dotchi Latham

comments.text: Im crying. Endo is horrible. ﻿
comments.author: ibti Horan

comments.text:
There seems to be a huge debate on WOMEN HAVE IT HARDER versus MEN HAVE IT 
HARDER. Both sexes come with their own set of difficulties. Women can have 
Endometriosis a terrible disease that nobody should suffer, but men can 
also have terrible diseases. Example: Priapism. An illness were you get a 
boner that lasts like 4+ hours. Have you ever felt that pain you get if you 
hold your arm up to long. Same thing, just much longer. ﻿
comments.author: TheMotoZ

comments.text: 176 million women?! I didn't know it was this common...﻿
comments.author: charlottesasaki

comments.text:
This runs heavily in my moms side of the family I have it also but I'm 
fortunate it's bearable for me with birth control hopefully we will have an 
actual cure for it one day﻿
comments.author: Merlena Leaser

comments.text:
I am so impressed to see Endo highlighted in this way. I too have 
endometriosis, and have been hospitalised for the entire month of Feb 
because of endometriomas (ovarian cysts caused by endo) and complications 
related to it. I was just catching up on the posts I've missed and this is 
what I see. It's heartwarming to see its importance finally being 
recognised. So many people really have no idea that a 'bad period' doesn't 
end for some women after 5-7, or 9 in my case, days of bleeding. I pray 
that you have the continued strength to keep going Lara, you and all the 
rest of us ladies out there.﻿
comments.author: Sasha Aimey

comments.text:
They should really do this whole segment on the lives of Chronic Illness 
sufferers, or Spoonies should I say, like they do with LGBT, dating, and 
other things. Just so people understand where we're coming from and our 
struggles. And on Varieties of illnesses, diseases, and disorders too. It's 
not simple, but every once in a while, theres light that no one else will 
understand or appreciate unless they live our lives. And theres even some 
humor in there about it, like the idiotic things people say to us because 
they don't understand. Like I'm saying, it's not all terrible though 
(mostly) but not always. Our bright days are the brightest, and its lovely. 
Awareness should be a thing, I don't know. I think it might be a good idea 
to display it, just a little deeper.﻿
comments.author: Frankie Marie

comments.text:
I go through something similar with the disease I have. It is really hard 
sometimes, and very easy to hate your body for what it's doing, but I know 
in time it has to be forgiven and things will get easier. ﻿
comments.author: Captain Kat

comments.text: men have it hard﻿
comments.author: (。◕‿◕。) KAWAII

comments.text: It's amazing that she spoke out about this! Stay strong everyone. ﻿
comments.author: thestoriesthatlast

comments.text: cant you get a hysterectomy? ﻿
comments.author: juicyluxury

comments.text:
+juicyluxury I think you will find very few doctors would be willing to 
remove a younger woman's reproductive organs unless it is absolutely 
necessary...And even then they usually won't until they are older. Plus, it 
would mean that she would immediately go through menopause and have to take 
hormone replacement and stuff like that...Which can actually cause some 
people a lot of issues.
comments.author: Shannon O'Driscoll

comments.text:
+juicyluxury I think you will find very few doctors would be willing to 
remove a younger woman's reproductive organs unless it is absolutely 
necessary...And even then they usually won't until they are older. Plus, it 
would mean that she would immediately go through menopause and have to take 
hormone replacement and stuff like that...Which can actually cause some 
people a lot of issues.
comments.author: Shannon O'Driscoll

comments.text:
That is true but it made my life better and I am wheelchair free now :) 
Sometimes it's the little things I celebrate.
comments.author: Dotchi Latham

comments.text:
Removing the uterus, with or without the ovaries, doesn't cure the 
disorder. The cells, or implants, often stick to other surrounding organs 
causing inflammation wherever they go.
comments.author: rebecca garcia

comments.text:
+juicyluxury It's harder to get one than you think. Usually, because of 
insurance companies, you have to jump through flaming hoops and try all 
these different "treatments" before they will give you a hysterectomy. The 
up side is that the side effects from the treatments make endometriosis 
pale in comparison.
comments.author: Dotchi Latham

comments.text:
Yes, of course she could.   However, she would be left unable to bear 
children.  Granted, her disorder leaves her with the possibility of not 
getting pregnant, but there is still that possibility if I understand 
correctly.  With this being said, as a woman who has no desire to have 
children, if I were to deal with this, I would opt for a hysterectomy 
instead of just dealing with the pain.  Every woman is different and each 
want different things.  Hysterectomies can be sometimes screw up your body 
severely, so other treatments are the way to go up until you have no other 
option.
comments.author: Vashta Nerada

comments.text:
I have HORRIBLE periods I throw up, get nauseous and have unimaginably 
terrible cramps, (although I know I'm not the only one who has pain lol) 
and lately I've been having random periods of terrible cramps when I'm not 
on my period. I may have to look into this!﻿
comments.author: noooooooooooooooooo

comments.text:
My mom has this. She didn't even realize she had it till like 9 months ago. 
She had her uterus scraped in august and it had already started growing 
back so she just had all of her stuff taken out in December. It's hard to 
see people you love go through pain.﻿
comments.author: Raven Stone

comments.text:
One day at school i had the worst cramp EVER. I was sweating, cramping, i 
never vomited but i was sure close to it. Im scared i might have that. But 
its only happened once to e when it felt that bad and maybe it was just a 
once in a lifetime. Im not sure if i have it and i sure hope i don't. It 
felt so bad i was so pale and i was about to pass out.﻿
comments.author: sarah casteel

comments.text: i hate that Australian bitch!﻿
comments.author: hussain abdullah

comments.text:
Thank you so much for uploading this.  I'm dealing with this as well, a 
very extreme case of it, and it sucks.  Most people have never heard of it, 
and think I'm just being a "drama queen" which is a term I've had put on me 
because of this condition since I was 10.  It sucks.  It helps to know I'm 
not alone, because sometimes the guilt for being such a baby and not being 
stronger makes life seem...not quite worth it.  Thanks for sharing - I'm 
sorry for anyone else dealing with this issue as well.﻿
comments.author: Rose W. (Desert Rose)

comments.text:
I have a question, are there any kind of birth control pills or any other 
medication that can help? 
I had a "friend" before who said she had Endometriosis and she took a 
special kind of birth control pill that took away all the pain and made her 
stop bleeding more or less. 
But now when i've heard and read more about it i suspect she was lying 
about it
(I realized that she often lied and made up stories to get attention), 
horrible if she did... 
And i never saw her in pain or anything.. >.<﻿
comments.author: Saga Green

comments.text: I feel so sorry for Lara﻿
comments.author: The epic nahrwals

comments.text:
Laura. You are beautiful and your smile is amazing. I personally appreciate 
you for being candid about your illness. I pray for your peace of mind and 
better and happier days. Just by your story I can tell you are strong 
woman. Thank you for being you.﻿
comments.author: Alex Summers

comments.text:
Please READ!! I have gone through this and have fond treatment that works!  
I have suffered from endo since age 16 (I am now thirty) I have had two 
surgeries to remove the endo cells they migrated to through my uterus, 
including around my lower bowel. Because they pooled there, I had extreme 
pain having bowel movements, as well as during sex and menstruation 
(vomiting and double-over-cramps included). 

BUT, I have  an amazing gynecologist that suggested after my last surgery 
(age 21) that I take birth control on a continuous basis. This would 
inhibit you from ovulating every month, stopping menstruation that forms 
the endo cells which attach them self to other areas in your body. When you 
menstruate, these cells are "told" by hormones to inflame and "shed", as 
they are supposed to in your uterus - but as you know, when they attache to 
other areas of your body, it causes blinding pain and complications. Take 
the pill continuously = no menstruation = no no new formation of endo cells 
= no more PAIN! I have had numerous ultrasounds since, and no new 
endometriosis has formed since. I have  now been put on a three month on 
pill, 7 days off to have a total of 4 menstrual cycles a year, and they 
have been very manageable. There is hope, just find a better doctor that 
has options for you other than multiple surgeries!!﻿
comments.author: Pam Galli

comments.text: Why can she maybe not be able to have sex? Because of the pain?﻿
comments.author: lola fuchs

comments.text: Thank you for this. Thank you for making me feel like I am not alone.﻿
comments.author: Candice Degotte

comments.text:
Warning: This is not a story with a happy ending, but something that 
endometrial women should know as they age:
I am 58. I had treatment resistant endometriosis in my abdomen & pelvis for 
all of my 20's and some of my 30's. I had to take many sick days off work, 
and it often dropped me to me knees, wherever I might be standing (grocery 
store was the worst). My buddies would come over, wrap me up & take me to 
their place for days, The  'miracle' treatments of the day (1980's) was 
steroid hormone, major pain medications that I needed special authority 
for, hysterectomies and laparoscopies - where the offending cells are 
lasered (burnt) wherever they might have gone a-wandering. I did all those 
(9 laparoscopic treatments in all). Things were  great for about 20 years. 
At the beginning of my 50's, I started having episodes' similar (in that 
they were episodic, but the pain was 'different')
By 55 I was living with daily chronic pain from those laparoscopies and the 
endometriosis - they both leave scar tissue which are adhesions much like 
cement that develop over time and can get worse with passing years. If they 
are 'band type adhesions' there is relief through surgery, but it will come 
back. If its 'cobweb' type, they cannot be removed surgically. There only a 
few treatments out there, IMS, high-concentrations of vitamins injected 
into trigger points and the only one that has worked for me 300 mg slow 
release opiate combined with 60 mg cymbalta everyday. And for keeping big 
flares down, IMS. And for getting my brain to hep instead of hinde, a TENS 
machine, This get s me 4-8 hours a day of tolerable (as long as I dont 
engage is triggering activities. )I spent literally $10,000 on every 
conservative, alternative, & complementary treatment out there - and i live 
in a major city, diet, chinese medicine, homeopathy, yoga (ha!), infusions, 
ACT massage, Shiatsu, I could go on & on. Activities got harder and harder 
to do - try and think of an activity that doesnt involve your abdomen or 
pelvis. No cycling,playing tenni,  long walks, no dancing, no fencing no no 
exercise to get your hreat rate up. SO depression sets in, you may have to 
leave your job (I did) and its hard to maintain friendships because you 
cant do much. Grocery shopping, cooking and eating of food is herculean, so 
many of us just dont. It can get to the 'granny diet' of tea & toast if 
you're not careful. At present, there is no 'cure' or real research (that I 
know of) as
1) Its a womans health issue and 2) health authorities dont want to fund 
anything chronic at all - either physical, mental or emotional.
I was an out-going, vital woman who loved her job - it's been a horrible 
blow and I am still working on it so dont have many words of wisdom or 
anything, but I'll tell you - Keeping friendships alive is the most 
important. Isolation is walking with the black dog. Do what you can when 
you can. Be important/of benefit to another human being (volunteer or work 
if you can). A good therapist is a treaure (if you can afford one) - and 
support groups can be great places to offer/get support & share info.
And remember it ok to get mad sometimes - at the illness or lack of medical 
support- but not at yourself. YOU didn't cause this.﻿
comments.author: April Porter

comments.text:
U should try medical cannabis (marijuana) to help cope with the pain and 
nausea. It helped me.﻿
comments.author: Kanye West

comments.text:
I suffered through so much through high school, I was really angry at my 
body.﻿
comments.author: Polymath8881

comments.text:
I have fibromyalgia. People often think I'm faking it or it's not that bad. 
It is bad. It is awful. The pain and fatigue are overwhelming and it's hard 
to accurately explain that to people who don't know what it feels like. I'm 
a father of a beautiful 21 month old son, and I worry about the future when 
he wants to play sports with me or something like that and I have to try to 
explain that daddy can't do that. It affects your entire life. I'll be this 
way forever, and it may get worse too. I can relate when she said she's mad 
at her body for doing this to her. My body feels like a prison and I have 
to try and live within those confines. It sucks but I am glad it's not 
terminal. I want to see my son grow up, even if I can't do everything I 
want to with him and for him. ﻿
comments.author: Michael Pappano

comments.text:
+Izzy Noel I have RA as well. I was diagnosed at 15, I'm now almost 20. I 
totally understand. people don't get it at all, especially when we're this 
young. people my age don't have any idea what this kind of pain feels like, 
and like you said, it's invisible. so its hard for my friends to understand 
what I'm going through, and what I'm going to have to go through for my 
entire life most likely. I'm glad you're in remission though!
comments.author: Kyleigh McSherry

comments.text:
+Dotchi Latham I know how you feel. I know, and the others here know that 
you are not lying. You have my sympathies, and I will hold a good thought 
for you, and the others here. Be strong, and try to find any happiness you 
can for yourself.
comments.author: Michael Pappano

comments.text:
People who have never experienced debilitating pain have no idea what it is 
like. There are days my bones feel like they are breaking, slowly 
fracturing as I make the smallest move, and my skin feels like someone has 
poured acid over me... but the doctors don't even want to help me and no 
one takes me seriously. I just sit in my house and cry quietly.
comments.author: Dotchi Latham

comments.text:
I used to have JRA (Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis) and thankfully I'm now 
in Remission, but everyone was like, "oh it doesn't hurt it doesn't matter 
it's nothing" they were treating it like it was a cold bc it is an 
invisible disease. It was crippling it got to the point were I would faint 
or be temporarily paralyzed bc of pain.
Like- it's a real thing.
comments.author: Izzy Noel

comments.text:
+Michael Pappano I cried when she said that. It perfectly explains how I 
feel in my body. It also explains how I feel in my mind when I have 
seizures, or just after them. I also have Fibromyalgia and it sucks hurting 
all the time. But, my kids are 16 and 19 and they understand that mom isn't 
able to be as active. We just find things we all enjoy so we can spend time 
together.
comments.author: Dotchi Latham

comments.text:
i'm sorry to hear that! i'm sure your son will understand, and hey not all 
fun things are physical , i'm sure you will find a way :)
comments.author: Mariah Jones

comments.text: +LEXI thank you.
comments.author: Michael Pappano

comments.text:
I have fibromyalgia too, and a thyroid disease. So I understand your pain. 
Along with my entire body hurting, my hormones are also out of whack 
sometimes, so I can become a real bitch when i'm in pain. I'm sorry that 
you have this, but you will be okay. Your son will love you and understand, 
and if anything he will look up to you for being so strong and carrying on 
when times are tough.
comments.author: LEXI

comments.text:
When Lara said "My job is to sit at a desk and write and sometimes I can't 
even do that." really hit home with me. I have a chronic invisible illness 
and I'm constantly in pain. My last job was sitting at a desk and at least 
2 days out of the work week I wasn't able to do it because of the pain. It 
just really sucks because you want to work and you know that you need to 
but you just can't. Then you get people that look at you like you're 
inadequate and lazy. Let's not mention the depression that normally comes 
with chronic illnesses. It sucks. A lot. I wish Lara all the best and hope 
there are many pain free days in her future. ﻿
comments.author: Jessie Says

comments.text:
I don't know how you feel and never will, because you're a woman. I'm a 
man. I can't have this, but I know how you feel in another way... I do have 
a Chronic Illness. I have Type 1 Diabetes. And... It's awful... I won't 
even bother explaining it, I doubt people wanna hear me complain about my 
life. I get yelled at enough already for it...﻿
comments.author: Tek Solstice

comments.text:
you have a right to feel however you want to feel. and people shouldn't 
yell at you for being a human. we should all want to hear, it's how we 
learn and how we understand.
comments.author: Mariah Jones

comments.text: I have endometriosis, and fucking hell it is terrible :(﻿
comments.author: Liv McShane

comments.text: I have the same thing endometriosis :(﻿
comments.author: farah R-D

comments.text:
I kinda understand the feeling of being "broken", not because of 
Endometriosis, but because of vulvar vestibulitis and vaginismus. 
It really sucks, both for me and for my partner! But he is still here even 
if I can't have sex the way we want to.
So I mean, it can work out even if you can't have sex, that's good to know 
:) ﻿
comments.author: Engulkyckling

comments.text:
I started crying almost immediately. I suffer from endometriosis and it is 
so incredibly difficult. This video was refreshing. Its nice to feel like 
you're not alone. 
I have friends that will say they have cramps, take some advil and will be 
fine.
I'll have cramps or back pain that is so disabling it brings me to my knees.

This video is so great because there needs to be a conversation.﻿
comments.author: Rachel Lofton

comments.text:
Thank you for reminding me that there are other out there with chronic 
illness. It helps me remember the just because I have bad days does not 
mean I am a bad person.﻿
comments.author: IceBlueCrystalShadow

comments.text:
Nothing is worse than feeling like a damaged women. I was married before I 
had symptoms and for the last year I haven't been able to have sex. He does 
understand but I know he is frustrated , hell I can't even get aroused 
without having cramps. These cramps are crippling but every women is 
different with endometriosis, I get 15 minute intense cramps that extend my 
stomach and it is awful﻿
comments.author: MarinneV

comments.text:
I suffer from a autoimmune disease known as Lupus, and a genetic disease 
known as Ehler Danlos. You're line "I was letting people treat me like crap 
because I felt like I had to make up for the fact that I was broken." Spoke 
so truly to me. My issue may not be the same, but is a chronic illness that 
gives me so much pain. I can't do many things with my friends and I am 
terrified for what my life will hold. I take cancer patient medication and 
I could possibly not have children because of it. It's terrifying. I love 
the fact that you made this video. Maybe people will start to understand 
that chronic pain doesn't just go away with a pill, it lasts forever. There 
is nothing to be done. So, thank you and, have faith. Life will get better, 
stay strong <3﻿
comments.author: Kayla VanderLaan

comments.text:
Can we see more videos like this but on different illnesses? I was 
diagnosed with an autoimmune disease at 8 years old, was on cancer 
medications to kill off white blood cells, and have since been diagnosed 
with 2 more conditions due to the autoimmune disease (Hashimoto's 
Hypothyroidism and Sjogren's Syndrome). I also am diagnosed with severe 
anxiety and panic attacks. Videos like this make me feel normal. <3 Thank 
you.  ﻿
comments.author: Cassandra Summit

comments.text:
Doctors who say "Oh, you just have bad periods" piss me off so much. I had 
to say something to me doctor 3 times at least before she gave me higher 
strength painkiller. I don't have anything like this, thank goodness, but 
in terms of the pain I've personally experienced in my life, my period 
cramps are THE worst.﻿
comments.author: Christine Stevenson

comments.text:
I definitely know the feeling of feeling less than a woman. Although, I do 
not have endometriosis, I do have PCOS. ﻿
comments.author: mwinters
